descendants.content:
@Ulrich_the_elder

1 - helpful to pressure politicians to ratify a *more stringent* global policy reducing plastics production

2 - helpful to spur more research into impact of microplastics on health and how to counter the impacts

3 - helpful to increase demand for utilities to filter water better, put mandatory plastic traps on washing machines/dryer

4 - a thousand other ways that identifying the severity of the problem helps to find the solution(s)

https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2024/08/us-support-plastic-production-limits-industry-un-treaty-negotiations/

card.title: New US support for global production limits has the plastics industry in a tizzy
card.description: The Biden administration's reversal could prove influential in upcoming treaty talks.

descendants.content:
@Ulrich_the_elder Personally, I've long filtered my water as much as possible, and that's one route microplastics get into the body. Another is eating fresh organic foods (less processing = less plastics). Another is generally reducing the amount of plastics in your environment (meaning, to the extent possible, reducing plastic packaging, especially things like single use plastics in water bottles, takeout containers, etc).

But reality is microplastics are ubiquitous & this is a global problem.

descendants.content:
@Ulrich_the_elder the reality is that if we only care about our own personal health and no one else's — if we think pollution only matters once it enters our own personal bodies — then we will never make any progress in saving lives and cleaning the planet much less living sustainably.

Thankfully, lots of people care about more than themselves and are working on this problem. The more attention it gets the more quickly we'll find solutions.
